column1: "As COVID-19 causes simultaneous health and economic crises worldwide, it also presents an opportunity for governments to re-evaluate their investments, giving health higher priority." https://t.co/RFI2SAcIwl

“It is hard to imagine any health intervention that would be more cost-effective,” Theo Vos, professor of health metrics sciences at the IHME, tells CNBC Make It. “Even if causing a small amount of discomfort to everyone.” https://t.co/dYHH5PuDNa

“Racism is a public health issue,” said Dr. @AliHMokdad with the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. “I’ve been on record saying it’s more dangerous than COVID-19, simply because we're going to find a vaccine for COVID-19.”  https://t.co/2zR5bulnLF

"As the world quietly passes the six-month anniversary of the @WHO designation of the novel coronavirus as a public health emergency of international concern, it’s hardly news that COVID-19 has impacted some countries much more than others." https://t.co/khmdqO7VrH

b'.@IHME_UW released today #COVID19 projections for Indonesia. It is imperative for all Indonesians to do their part to prevent the spread of the virus. https://t.co/f20Ntw2VxJ'

"Even without strict laws, Japan has been largely successful in keeping coronavirus at bay. Because mask-wearing in Japan is nearly culturally universal, as of July 9, the country has recorded less than 1,000 total deaths from COVID-19." https://t.co/XwHhwvQK3m

Under the large-scale social distancing mandates, human mobility has been reduced to 21.3% below pre-COVID levels. The forecasts assume that under the “new normal” policy and gradual easing of the social distancing mandates, there will be a corresponding increase in mobility. https://t.co/yj4fTR0ZXm

The forecasts to November 1 show the epidemic in Indonesia continuing to grow. The model is projecting that Indonesia’s need for ICU beds for COVID-19 patients will exceed the beds available in the beginning of September if this trend proves accurate. https://t.co/jfa2IlVp9M

“These new forecasts underscore the burden of COVID-19 and the imperative for all Indonesians to actively do their part in helping prevent the spread of the virus,” said Dr. Nafsiah Mboi, former minister of health of the Republic of Indonesia and current IHME board member. https://t.co/18c8AfvcPK

We retrospectively calculated the error in cumulative mortality compared to subsequently observed trends by number of weeks of model extrapolation up to six weeks. We used the median absolute percent error (MAPE) as a measure of accuracy. https://t.co/EckPgfGAQa

We strongly believe decision makers should draw on a variety of models. We respect these #COVID19 modelers, and appreciate the ways that their models differ from our own:  @covid_analytics  @LosAlamosNatLab  @youyanggu  @imperialcollege

To create this framework, we have reviewed 93 published and unpublished COVID-19 forecasting models and have comprehensively evaluated six models for which publicly available, multinational, and date-versioned mortality estimates could be downloaded (see table below). https://t.co/Gdfhkx6QOh
We are excited to share preliminary work on the creation of such a framework as a public good to aid researchers and policymakers in critically and systematically assessing model performance.
How well is our model performing? Introducing a global framework for COVID-19 mortality forecast comparisons. https://t.co/YayZnjshmA

Unless concerted action occurs, any other locations in Brazil are currently predicted to have rising daily COVID-19 death rates through June and beyond.

Daily COVID-19 death rates in Brazil in some places (e.g., Amazonas, Para) may have experienced their predicted peaks, however, their downward epidemic trajectories are much more gradual, and thus daily COVID-19 deaths could remain fairly high for weeks ahead. https://t.co/wUX6dCx6qh
However, the US has about 100 million more people than Brazil. This means, relative to each country’s population size, Brazil’s COVID-19 epidemic could be the largest and most lethal globally.

Current predictions point to Brazil having among the worst COVID-19 epidemics in the world. The US has the next highest projected COVID-19 death toll through August, at 140,496 cumulative deaths (estimate range of 134,395 to 146,999).
Based on the latest data and disease patterns, the country’s epidemic curve suggests that COVID-19 deaths will continue escalating in the coming weeks or months.
A focus on #Brazil:   Nationally, cumulative #COVID19 projections indicate 165,960 deaths (estimate range of 113,673 to 253,131) could occur in Brazil by August.

To clarify, this is at the U.S. county-level.
And finally, for details on #COVID19 model updates, we recommend bookmarking our Update Notes blog: https://t.co/rxnSezeViU
That's a wrap. Thank you for having us, @IANPHIhealth. Have a question that wasn't answered in the Q&A or FAQ blog? Our DM's are open! https://t.co/FgLhBPTh34
Dr. Murray says that we plan to provide #COVID19 estimates at the county-level.
Q: What is the relationship between smoking prevalence and likeliness of contracting #COVID19?  A: We have tried plugging this into our model, but have found no significant relationship.

Dr. Murray says that because we have so much mobility data, the variable that reduces mobility the most is school closures. Not because of kids not going to school, he says, but because of all the associated social interactions with school (parents dropping kids off, etc.).

Q: What's bringing down transmission right now?  A: Testing, seasonality and mask use, says Dr. Murray. He adds that the trend into the future is driven by the expansion of mobility, which will likely increase transmission.

Dr. Murray says it has been hard to find COVID-19 daily admissions data. Some people report the daily census, so the number of people with the Covid diagnosis in hospitals. But daily admissions would be best for us. If anybody knows places collecting this data, please reach out.

Q: Where do we get our data from?   A: @JohnsHopkins for national #COVID19 data, subnational data directly from various governments, and @WHO for hospital data. "Whenever anybody wants to give us better data than what we're using, we'd like to incorporate it," said Dr. Murray.
For answers to frequently asked questions, check out our #COVID19 Model's FAQ Blog: https://t.co/YjPzARRcn1
Now it's time for Q&A https://t.co/oLAmlm1YIX

Dr. Murray points out how our model reliably predicted #COVID19 peaks, but struggled with other predictions.   We have been evaluating our model's performance, and have been making changes to it's methodologies so that we can make sure we have reasonably good prediction error.

Incorporating this new model into our broader COVID-19 estimation platform sets the foundation for substantially expanding included locations.

While the new death model does not substantially affect estimates for most locations, especially those with larger epidemics, its performance is more robust in handling daily fluctuations in reported deaths & cases, and also for locations with smaller epidemics to date.

Our improved COVID-19 death modeling strategy can be summarized as a 5 step process. In sum, we are now using a more parsimonious model than CurveFit, combining deaths and cases into a time series of estimated COVID-19 deaths for the past and predicted 8 days into the future. https://t.co/JNH5K3QNPR

We have a new approach to modeling deaths, an improvement spurred by the need to develop methods that are more robust in handling variable #COVID19 input data and perform well for smaller epidemics.   Details in our Update Notes: https://t.co/cK0AAOAGLp

Q: Why did you make substantial revisions to your model on 5/4?  A: Our new hybrid model approach allows us to better model the impact of recent developments on #COVID19 disease transmission & deaths, including easing of social distancing, increasing mobility & increased testing.
...to ensure that sufficient resources are in place. Many planners also prefer to utilize the upper range in their preparations.

Q: Do changes in your projections mean that hospitals may have overprepared?  A: We believe that it is better for health systems to prepare for the upper range of values in the forecast, instead of the middle or lower range... (Continued)

Q: Why have your estimates for hospital resource needs changed?  A: As data continue to come in, our estimates may change. Specifically, new death data and new information about the number of COVID-19 patients who need hospital beds have changed our projections.
Q: Why are you estimating hospital capacity?  A: These forecasts were developed to help hospitals and health systems prepare for the surge of COVID-19 patients.

Q: How did you determine the infection fatality ratio?  A: We reviewed data from all locations where extensive COVID-19 testing has occurred, then used the infection fatality ratio from the locations where the ratios were lowest: the Diamond Princess cruise ship and New Zealand.

Q: How do you define estimated infections .v. confirmed infections?  A: We define estimated infections as prevalent infections – all cases that exist in a location on a given day, not just new ones. Confirmed infections are those that have been identified through testing.

Q: Social distancing measures haven't been eased in my location. Why does your tool show mobility increasing?   A: We are using anonymized mobile phone data to measure mobility, which indicates that mobility has increased in your location despite mandated distancing measures.
Mobility is an indicator of greater potential for personal contact which contributes to the spread of the disease. When mobility is high, the risk of COVID-19 spreading is also high.

Q: What do you mean by "mobility"?  A: Mobility refers to personal movement by a population and is based on anonymous cellphone data several technology companies have made available for the purposes of fighting COVID-19. (Continued)

Insufficient testing (testing that doesn’t keep pace with infections) as well as insufficient contact tracing capabilities, or lack of isolation for known infections, could also contribute to this rise.
Q: Why does the dotted line for infections grow more rapidly in certain places?  A: Increases in mobility and loosening of social distancing measures can drive up infections. (Continued)

If testing in a particular location falls below estimated infections, the risk of undetected community transmission increases. Public health officials need to monitor these two indicators closely to determine when social distancing measures can be eased.

Q: What do the metrics around testing and infections tell us?  A: Comparing these two metrics, which represent testing and estimated infections on a given day, shows how well the public health system is tracking the epidemic. (Continued)

.@AliHMokdad: As we address these types of health issues in the United States, we must identify where they're coming from. Yes, there's some personal responsibility to living in good health, but we also need layers of support from the local and national governments.
Next question:   Is good health a right or an obligation?

Dr. Albert Wettstein: We need to understand that states and health insurance companies ought to provide the least harmful substance free of charge to people who are struggling with addiction disorders.

@AliHMokdad: We have centers in the United States that are exclusively for mental health, and centers exclusively for physical health. These conditions don't exist in a silo. How can you treat one without the other?
Dena Morris: Bringing in community health care workers who can provide preventive services could perhaps have the biggest impact in the United States.
Dr. Albert Wettstein: We need focus on innovation for elderly people, and the quality of medical care they receive, and their access to it.

.@AliHMokdad: I have a 19-year-old daughter, and I know firsthand that this younger generation thinks differently than the way us older people think. We need to encourage them to concentrate on solutions. They blow my mind with the things they come up with.
Now it's time for the Q&A. The first question is, "What advice do you have for innovators?"
Dena Morris: We used to say in the United States Senate, "we invest in what we measure."
.@AliHMokdad: I believe a quality hospital is the one that provides the best preventative health services in the community. We must invest in prevention.
Dena Morris: In the United States, we really value our freedom — sometimes at the cost of a greater public good.

Dr. Albert Wettstein: Paying for health insurance often doesn't lead to a good return on your money. We have a national initiative in Switzerland demanding to have an insurance system, and the population at large didn't want it. The people want immediate optimal care.

.@AliHMokdad: We are facing a deficit of over $500 million at @UWMedicine, where I work right now. Keeping that in mind is very important. So while people are in crisis, so is our medical system. https://t.co/cX47r6495i

Dr. Albert Wettstein: United States has the best hospitals in the world, has the best academic teachers in the world, but this doesn't reach the people at large.

As for next steps: our team is currently exploring how such data and corresponding estimates can be incorporated into our modeling approach, as well as expanding the data sources and locations included for measuring mask use.
Nonetheless, using masks when in public appears to be another important tool in curbing COVID-19’s toll.

Cloth masks or face coverings cannot fully prevent viral transmission, and their use should go hand-in-hand with other important actions to avoid close contact with others, especially while most places are still scaling up robust containment measures.

Given that cloth masks or face coverings have been shown to reduce transmission risk, these preliminary findings highlight the role of broader mask use as more states ease stay-at-home orders and other types of social distancing policies.
As shown in the map below, for the week of May 9 to May 15, at least 80% of survey respondents in 18 states said they sometimes or always wore masks when leaving their home. https://t.co/K3uH9fex4U
With these caveats in mind, our team ran exploratory analyses to examine whether any patterns emerged regarding mask use within the US.

They are also based on a convenience sample, and thus users are not formally sampled to receive the interview; subsequently, it is not clear if these data are representative of each state’s broader populations beyond those who use @premisedata and are contributors.
Such data are collected on a daily basis from contributors, which means these data are subject to various limitations related to self-reporting of behaviors.
One topical area covers the use of masks or cloth face coverings, asking app users whether they always, sometimes, or never use masks when they leave their homes.
.@PremisesStudios, a crowd-sourcing data collection company, is currently collecting sentiment data on COVID-19 through its 1.8 million contributors in 100 countries.
Yet such a #COVID19 surge has yet to materialize, suggesting that increases in human mobility alone may not fully capture risk of transmission.

With mobility rising throughout the US over the last several weeks, our team had expected to see large increases in reported COVID-19 cases and deaths in more recent days. After all, the time lag between heightened mobility & potential rise in infections is approximately 2 weeks.

It is worth noting that we have not yet formally incorporated mask use into our broader estimation framework; this in-progress work offers important insights into the ever-changing dimensions of human behavior and its relationship to COVID-19 pandemic.

Our 5/18 #COVID19 projections update provides more information on a new area of work – quantifying the general public’s mask use in the United States – as well as a summary of key results in the US based on the latest available data. https://t.co/cK0AAOAGLp

Prediction indicate that demand for ICU beds could exceed #Mexico’s current capacities; these patterns could change if #COVID19 epidemic trajectories shift.
#Brazil’s estimates of ICU demand could surpass current capacities, with an estimated need of 6,836 (4,966 to 10,936), and 4,060 ICU beds available.

For instance, at the national level, #Peru may be experiencing some of the most acute shortages, with predicted need of 1,040 ICU beds (estimate range of 793 to 1,677), with an estimated 88 available.
While potential shortages may also occur in the future, our estimates suggest that substantial shortages could already be happening in several locations.

With today’s release, we also publish a first set of estimates for hospital resource demand – total hospital beds, ICU beds, and invasive ventilators – for these locations. Based on the latest available data, demand for ICU beds could exceed current capacities in many countries.

Our current forecasting lasts through 8/4. Subsequent projections likely will extend into October and will include potential effects of students returning to school.  The 5/10 announcement covers only the US and individual states. New forecasts on other nations are coming soon.

“Unless and until we see accelerated testing, contact tracing, isolating people who test positive, and widespread use of masks in public, there is a significant likelihood of new infections," Dr. Murray said.

“While at least some of these patterns may be related to formal easing of social distancing policies, this upward trend in movement began in several places long before state-level mandates were relaxed,” Dr. Murray said.

“We’re also seeing fewer deaths expected in some states; however, we’re now forecasting slower downward trajectories in deaths after states hit their peaks in daily deaths," said our Director Dr. Christopher Murray.

Anonymized cell phone data from @Facebook, @DescartesLabs, @Google, and @SafeGraph allows us to identify the likely impact of social distancing measures in the absence of formal mandates.   Learn more: https://t.co/YjPzARRcn1 https://t.co/Vv1TCnW7jN
“The increase is explained primarily by people’s movements, as captured in anonymous mobility data from cell phones,” said our Director Dr. Christopher Murray.

In the words of @FiveThirtyEight:   "...COVID-19 models aren’t made to be unquestioned oracles. They’re not trying to tell us one precise future, but rather the range of possibilities given the facts on the ground." https://t.co/cdICAfQIUo
Relative to baseline levels of mobility, most states experienced substantive declines in mobility by late March or early April.
We show changes in the composite mobility indicator over time, as well as predictions, overlaid against the timing of social distancing policy implementation – and for some locations, easing.

Several states with large epidemics are following a similar trajectory (e.g., New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts); New York is the main exception, with its predicted peak in early-mid April and gradual downward trend in predicted deaths.
Our updated modeling approach indicates that the US appears to be in a prolonged epidemic peak, averaging near or over 2,000 predicted COVID-19 deaths a day for the last few weeks.
Further, for a subset of states, the easing of social distancing policies has begun and mobility patterns are on the rise (or even started increasing before easing actions occurred).

Based on the latest available data and updated models, most of these states are currently experiencing or have yet to experience their epidemic peaks – all of which appear to be lasting longer and declining more slowly after their peaks.
While these states have generally been among those with the highest predicted tolls from COVID-19, each of their cumulative death projections have increased by at least 2,000.

Prof. Emmanuela Gakidou shares how our model has evolved over the last several weeks. With our new modeling framework, we aim to provide a venue through which different #COVID19 epidemic scenarios & responses can be explored by location. https://t.co/u1reZsWql4
Testing has scaled up in many parts of the world, but such progress has been uneven and is not keeping pace with the growing demand for lifting business and gathering restrictions.

We, collectively, are now entering a new phase of the COVID-19 pandemic. More locations are easing previously implemented social distancing policies, and human mobility patterns are trending upward – even in places where distancing measures remain in place.

This shift upward since 4/17 is mainly due to retrospective data updates that many states conduct as they are able to complete data backlogs.

Across the US, the predicted peak for daily #COVID19 deaths appeared to be on 4/15, reaching 2,688 deaths. This is a slightly higher peak value for 4/15 since our 4/17 release (2,481 daily COVID-19 deaths) and very similar to our 4/31 release (2,671).

The 4/22 release is higher than the average US predictions for cumulative #COVID19 deaths published on 4/17 (60,308 with an estimate range of 34,063 to 140,381) and 4/21 (64,976, with an estimate range of 45,375 to 124,120) though the uncertainty intervals still overlap markedly.
Based on our latest estimates, the US could reach 67,641 cumulative deaths (estimate range of 48,058 to 123,157) during the #COVID19 epidemic’s first wave.   (Thread)

Projections suggest that Ontario and Quebec could have the largest toll in Canada, at 1,953 (1,186 to 4,101) and 1,481 (761 to 3,629) cumulative COVID-19 deaths, respectively. Initial projections for Canada and provinces with 50 or more cumulative deaths are listed below. https://t.co/DKyaMHon9H
Based on the latest available data, cumulative COVID-19 deaths could reach 4,544 (estimate range of 2,176 to 11,750) through the epidemic’s first wave in Canada.
This corresponds with the peak for #Quebec, which reported 143 COVID-19 deaths that day.   #Ontario’s projected epidemic peak likely occurred on April 17, with 55 COVID-19 deaths
Shifting to #Canada:   Nationally, Canada may have reached its epidemic peak for #COVID19 deaths on April 16, when 183 daily deaths occurred.

As emphasized in our April 17 release, these projections could change as new data become available and/or different policies are implemented. This is particularly true for states with comparatively fewer COVID-19 deaths (for example, North Dakota, Kansas, Arizona).

Importantly, the four other states had initial date predictions in June, a time period that is inherently less certain than estimates for May – especially when updated data inputs occur in terms of location-days.

Subsequently, Washington’s descent from its epidemic peak is now slower than previously estimated – and thus the projected timing of potentially easing distancing measures is being pushed back further as well.

For instance, in Washington state, an uptick in daily COVID-19 deaths captured in time series between the April 17 release (input data through April 16) and yesterday’s release (input data through April 20) increased the state’s total COVID-19 deaths to date by 30.

Except for North Dakota, these states appear to have already experienced peaks in daily COVID-19 deaths, but the duration and shapes of their downward trajectories are changing as updated data can be incorporated into the models.
The updated death model, which now uses COVID-19 cases as a leading indicator to predict epidemic peak and overall shape, has resulted in longer peaks and tails for many states.

The exact reasons why the dates have shifted are unique to each state, but some shared characteristics are present. First, all five states now have higher cumulative COVID-19 death projections since the April 17 release.

Between our first release on April 17 and the release on April 21 on potential timing for easing distancing measures in the US, states shifted an average of 1.3 days later; the median, a metric less sensitive to outliers, was 0 days.

For some places, this may be an underestimate of public health capacity – in others, it could remain ambitious until containment efforts are scaled up. If or as such data become available, they can also be incorporated into the models.
This threshold is viewed as a conservative estimate of what locations could potentially identify via active case detection and contact tracing given available public health resources.
...and when these projections fall below 1 prevalent infection per 1,000,000 population for the upper bound of the 95% uncertainty interval.
These estimated dates are based on projections of all-age #COVID19 prevalent infections – that is, all occurring infections in a location, not just new ones... (continued)
Further, we are pleased to announce that our updated manuscript, including up-to-date technical appendices, is now available online: https://t.co/MVv3kCSZcZ
As we add new locations to our production pipeline, we will focus on producing estimates for locations that have reported a minimum of 50 cumulative deaths to date.

.@AliHMokdad: Once this initial pandemic of coronavirus dies down, and social distancing measures are removed, we must devise effective strategies to protect our country from another pandemic.

Now, during the #COVID19 crisis, @AliHMokdad says it’s his turn to help others:   “I am lucky to have a stable job as a professor at the @UW. It’s imperative that people like me who are still earning a living help those who can’t.” https://t.co/iPUnQLKu8h

.@AliHMokdad: The owner kept the restaurant open until he ran out of food. Other restaurants in Beirut did the same. I’ll never forget the acts of kindness that I experienced during that time. https://t.co/pKsxuh9Njc
.@AliHMokdad: A restaurant nearby that we used to frequent for sandwiches (Marrouche) gave me and other stranded students free meals, telling us 'you can pay us back when you can.'

.@AliHMokdad: In summer of 1982, I lived in a dorm, Penrose Hall. As the war intensified, our university cafeteria closed, few stores remained open, and my fellow students and I ran out of food and money. The roads were closed, so our parents could not reach us.

.@AliHMokdad  "I was born in a rural farming village, Lassa, in Mount Lebanon. My parents struggled to put food on the table. After graduating from high school, I attended @AUB_Lebanon to study #biostatistics. During my time there, the Lebanese civil war was raging. https://t.co/q6zFQjebVI

.@milesobrien: What do you see ahead?  Dr. Bundesmann: We are now at a state where I think we can keep this pace we have going, and that's a good thing because of how many susceptible people are still susceptible to #COVID19. It's going to be a long haul, I think.  #frontlinePBS

Pulmonary Physician, Michael Bundesmann, at @EvergreenHosp says:   We can feel the curve flattened... that's allowed us to see patients and take care of them at a pace that our ICU can handle volume-wise. That's certainly made a big difference."  #frontlinePBS

.@milesobrien: Really? Exactly the rate of death and hospitalizations that we're dealing with?  Dr. Murray: Pretty much. We're not going to want to take off [social distancing] measures by May 1. Lets put it that way.  #frontlinePBS
Dr. Murray: So then if you take [social distancing] measures off May 1st, there's a pretty quick rebound. So by mid-July, we'd be right back to where we are now.   #frontlinePBS
Dr. Murray: It may not be anywhere near enough to be able to do full scale mass testing.   #frontlinePBS

.@milesobrien: There's no scenario going forward that you can envision that doesn't demand mass-testing, or testing for everyone?   Dr. Murray: The issue will be the capacity to test. How many tests are practically feasible come June, state by state?   #frontlinePBS

@Rob_Bee_Gee She will not. They use a messenger RNA sequence that has a similar shape to the coronavirus to see if she will produce antibodies effective against COVID-19. They are testing her blood to see if she produces said antibodies.

After telling people about her involvement, Rebecca says that many reached out to ask how they too can participate.  "I'm really fortunate to be in good enough health to participate in this trial, and to do something that could have such a positive impact on the world," she said.

Rebecca will take her temperature every day for the next eight days, and will visit the clinic for two more follow-ups within two weeks. She'll check-in infrequently over the course of a year after that. She says that she hasn't experienced anything out of the ordinary. https://t.co/qFhelNMI3v

Our estimates released today use the 23 state-specific ratios noted below, and for states without state-specific ratios, the pooled ratio of 6.6 (95% confidence interval of 6.2 to 7.1) is applied. https://t.co/7sNkWJ6Gjv
To account for this new evidence in our current COVID-19 death modeling framework, we have adjusted covariate values on social distancing for Denmark, the Netherlands, and Norway.

Since our April 10 release, we received feedback from several collaborators in the Global Burden of Disease (GBD) network on how social distancing policies were being implemented – and having effects on population-level movement – in Denmark, the Netherlands, and Norway.

In a similar vein, we have used Illinois’s Department of Health (@IDPH) COVID-19 website to re-extract daily death data and benchmark inputs against the state’s routinely updated 30-day cumulative COVID-19 death count.

We have added an additional data source for Colorado, given reporting inconsistencies observed in our previous data source. The new data source is the daily death data reported through Colorado’s Department of Public Health and Environment (@CDPHE) website.

.@IHME_UW’s analysis of #COVID19 is based on an extensive range of information and data sources including local and national governments, @WHO, social distancing policies, utilization data on hospital beds and ICU capacity, ICU demand in #Italy, and age-specific deaths rates.

“We hope these forecasts will help leaders of medical systems figure out innovative ways to deliver high-quality care to those who will need their services in the coming weeks,” said Dr. Christopher Murray, Director of @IHME_UW.

.@IHME_UW’s analysis of #COVID19 will be updated regularly as a source of “real-time” information for hospital system administrators and local, state, and federal health policymakers. Download the latest estimates »https://t.co/VpCtwX9iX1
The end of the #COVID19 pandemic, defined as fewer than 10 deaths per day nationwide, will occur with the highest probability in the beginning of June for the United States.

.@IHME_UW’s state-by-state data analysis – based on observed death rates and existing social distancing measures – estimates that over the next four months, between 38,000 and 162,000 people in the US will die from the virus.

“Our estimated trajectory of COVID-19 deaths assumes continued and uninterrupted vigilance by the general public, hospital and health workers, and government agencies,” said Dr. Christopher Murray, Director of @IHME_UW.

Deaths related to the current wave of #COVID19 in the US are likely to persist into July, assuming people protect themselves and their communities by strongly adhering to social distancing measures and by taking other precautions advised by public health officials.

“The trajectory of the (#COVID19) pandemic will change – and dramatically for the worse – if people ease up on social distancing or relax with other precautions,” said Dr. Christopher Murray, Director of @IHME_UW. https://t.co/grhUz6AqwU

A: I also had the great fortune of working at WHO during the era when Gro Harlem Brundtland was the first female Director-General. She is one of the most impressive and inspiring individuals I have ever come across. 2/2

Q: What woman has inspired you (personally or professionally) and why?  A: I am inspired every day by watching my students and mentees make a difference by being confident, yet kind; ambitious, yet team players; excellent researchers, yet compassionate individuals. 1/2

A: Concerted action is required to make a difference for the world’s most vulnerable women. We have demonstrated that it’s possible; it’s now time to focus our efforts and energy on those who need it the most. 2/2

Q: What challenges toward equality will the next generation of women face?  A: The most pressing inequalities are in countries where women face inequality in all important dimensions of life, including income, education, social, and political participation. 1/2

A: Among my friends today, all of us have graduated university (and most graduate school, too) and are successful professionals. This is a remarkable change within one generation and only one of the many examples of progress towards gender equality. 2/2

Q: How has equality for women improved in your lifetime, as compared to your grandmother’s generation?  A: I grew up in Greece. The vast majority of my friends’ mothers did not have tertiary education and were not working. 1/2

In celebration of #InternationalWomensDay, we asked Prof Emmanuela Gakidou, Associate Chair for Academic Programs and Sr Director of Org Development & Training at IHME, a few questions on what #GenerationEquality means to her. https://t.co/EU8XA9xkiK
A: As a reminder, I have a book on “South Asian Superwomen” on my coffee table to remind myself of all of the unsung heroes paving the way for young girls. 3/3
A: In particular, women in the health and the biological sciences field have always had to be smarter, more organized, and more articulate than their male counterparts. 2/3

Q: What woman has inspired you (personally or professionally) and why?  A: I’m inspired by every woman who has been the “first” to succeed in their profession.  It takes great courage, ambition and resilience to win in a male dominated field. 1/3

A: While we have made substantial progress in opening doors for women, there is still more work to do.  The last few miles are always the hardest to climb – but we must keep encouraging the next generation to keep fighting for the privileges many men take for granted. 2/2

Q: What challenges toward equality will the next generation of women face?  A: Women in the next generation will need to overcome the apathy people have grown in response to the information they are inundated with daily. 1/2

A: My grandmother’s generation in Bangladesh, in contrast, certainly did not have such opportunities. I do not mean to say women back then did not have the same sense of purpose as women in my generation but our ability to pursue our own meaning to life has expanded greatly. 2/2

Q: How has equality for women improved in your lifetime, as compared to your grandmother’s generation?  A: I’m grateful to be born in a time where women are deemed more necessary and central to society in areas beyond family care. 1/2
In celebration of #InternationalWomensDay, we asked Tahiya Alam, Research Manager on the demographics team at IHME, a few questions on what #GenerationEquality means to her. https://t.co/C5wAXdph4a

Q: What woman has inspired you (personally or professionally) and why?  A: The woman who has inspired me personally is my mother. She is a strong hardworking woman. Despite all she has gone through, she is consistently encouraging, happy and with a positive attitude.

A: In addition, significant strides have been made in making formal education accessible to women and girls. There is still more that can be done in making the access equal to girls and boys, especially in the low income countries.
Q: What challenges toward equality will the next generation of women face?  A: Women participation and equal representation at global level of management, decision making and political processes.

Q: How has equality for women improved in your lifetime compared to your grandmother’s generation?  A: There are so many things that have changed over time. Women can now access decent work opportunities & have the right to make decisions on their sexual and reproductive health.

IHME’s Professor @simonihay with his friend, Professor Sir Charles Godfray. Thanks to Sir Godfray for speaking at IHME this morning! https://t.co/FHHs70cEr3
Sir Godfray believes we will see a significant shift in the way people eat in the next 20-30 years because of the promising potential of meat alternatives.

In conclusion, Sir Godfray says there are strong environmental and real but modest health arguments for eating less meat. We have limited policy tools to act on this, though... and social norms are changing in favor of reduced-meat diets.

If one wants to eliminate meat from their diet for health and environmental reasons, then Sir Godfray says it’s important to think of compelling narratives as to *why* you want to do this early and often.
But Sir Godfray again warns that it’s important to consider methane emissions when it comes to meat alternatives. https://t.co/H83T1vmtyL
So the question is, are meat alternatives better for the environment than meat?   And Sir Godfray says anything is better for the environment than meat, including meat alternatives.
Now we’re learning about meat alternatives, and the “fetishism” of protein. @oxfutureoffood
Sir Godfray shares Global Burden of Disease data forecasting avoided deaths per million people with a CO2 emissions tax. https://t.co/sjvn7JpzLv
Sir Godfray shares evidence from a @nature publication pointing to education about diets, and how education may change the way we *think* about what we eat, but not necessarily what we actually eat.

So how do we do better? Sir Godfray says if you are serious about changing the food system in such a way that will reduce greenhouse gas emissions:  -change your diet -help improve agricultural technology  -reduce waste @oxfutureoffood
“We all have to do better in different ways,” says Sir Godfray about global food consumption patterns.

.@oxfutureoffood Sir Godfray points to a correlation between foods that are bad for the environment, and foods that are bad for humans.  He says the inverse is true, too. Foods with relatively low impact on the environment have positive effects on humans.
Sir Godfray says there’s enormous potential in nitrogen recycling in China.
“If you’re worried about what’s going to happen in the next thirty or forty years... then you should concentrate on methane,” says Sir Godfray. https://t.co/62sEi6hyCD
“As the population excellerates, people are getting wealthier, and wealthier people tend to eat food that his more of an impact on the environment,” says Sir Godfray.
Animal products create an enormous amount of methane emissions — a very powerful, radiative warming, says Sir Godfray. https://t.co/JJdqSKoKy9
Sir Godfray shares data from @uk_biobank detailing that the consumption of red or processed meat 3-4 times a week led to 20% higher risk of colorectal cancer. https://t.co/Y8TbYSFZGb

Sir Godfray shares a graph made with our GBD Compare tool detailing the 2019 Global Burden of Disease Study’s results for the number of deaths at the global level attributable to diet. https://t.co/MjmEMCRjEY
Sir Godfray says the regional and projected global meat consumption is rising. China is in the lead, followed by Europe.
He’s speaking to IHME staff about meat consumption, health and the environment.
We’re pleased to have zoologist Professor Sir Charles Godfray from @oxfutureoffood with us at the Institute today!
